case_name: Director of Enforcement v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 701 of 1964 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 701 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 10, 1961 of Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 1428 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 10, 1961 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 1428 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal by certificate granted by High Court of Calcutta under Article 132 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate granted by the High Court of Calcutta under art. 132 1  of the Constitution

facts.text: High Court accepted petition under Article 226 and quashed adjudication proceedings under Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and is. directed against the judgment of the High Court accepting a petition under art. 226 of the Constitution and quashing adjudication proceedings under the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947

facts.text: Recovery in 1954 of some foreign currency and Travelers Cheques at No. 311, Bow Bazar Street, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: Following the recovery in 1954 of some foreign currency and Travelers Cheques at No. 311, Bow Bazar Street, Calcutta,

facts.text: Respondent along with his mother and brother carried on the business of jewellers at No. 311, Bow Bazar Street, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: where the respondent alongwith his, mother and brother, carried on the business of jewellers,

facts.text: Director of Enforcement issued notice on April 23, 1958 to respondent calling to show cause why adjudication proceedings should not be held for contravention of s.23(1) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the Director of Enforcement issued a numberice on April 23, 1958,on the petitioner calling upon him to show cause within 10 days of the receipt of the numberice why adjudication proceedings should number be. held against him for companytravention of s.23 1 of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent replied to notice on May 10, 1958 giving his version of possession of foreign currency, denied selling travellers cheques, prayed proceedings dropped and currency returned.

anchor.surface_text: On May 10, 1958, the respondent replied to the above memorandum giving his version as to how he came into possession of the foreign currency, but he denied having sold any travellers cheques. He prayed that the proceedings may be dropped and the currency seized returned to him.

facts.text: Director of Enforcement after considering reply concluded adjudication proceedings should be held and requested respondent to appear on May 13, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Director of Enforcement, after companysidering the cause shown by the respondent came to the companyclusion that the adjudication proceedings should be held. He, therefore, requested the respondent to arrange to be present either personally or through, his authorized representative before the Director on May 13, 1958,

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Article 226 on May 13, 1959 challenging adjudication proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: On, this, on May 13, 1959, the respondent filed a petition under art 226 of the Constitution challenging the adjudication proceeding -on various grounds,

facts.text: Principal grounds in petition: s.23(1)(a) and s.23D ultra vires Article 20(2), offence committed in 1954 so adjudication illegal without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: the principal grounds being that s. 23  1   a  and s. 23D of the Act were ultra vires of art. 20 2  of the Constitution, and that the offence having been companymitted in 1954, the -proposed adjudication was illegal and entirely without jurisdiction.

facts.text: High Court allowed petitioner to raise point that s.23(1)(a) and s.23D contravene Article 14 at final hearing.

anchor.surface_text: Before the High Court, at the time of the final hearing, the petitioner was allowed to raise the point that s. 23   1    a  as well as s. 23D companytravened art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Mitter J. held s.23(1)(a) violated Article 14 and ultra vires, and s.23D also condemned.

anchor.surface_text: Mitter, J. held that s. 23  1   a  violated art. 14 of the Constitution and was accordingly ultra vires the Constitution, and that the relative provision of s. 23D must also be companydemned.

facts.text: High Court held s.23(1)(a) substituted by Amending Act XXXIX of 1957 has no retrospective operation for offence in 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Regarding the second point, namely, whether s. 23  1   a , having, been substituted by the Amending Act XXXIX of 1957, would have retrospective operation in respect of the alleged offence, which took place in 1954,

facts.text: High Court quashed adjudication proceedings being without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, is stated before, the adjudication proceedings were quashed being without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Supreme Court held in Shanti Prasad Jain v. Director of Enforcement that s.23(1) and s.23D do not violate Article 14.

anchor.surface_text: This Court held in Shanti Prasad Jain v. Director of Enforcement 1  that s. 23 1  and s. 23D of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act did number violate art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondent's counsel concedes cannot press Article 14 point.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. P. K. Chatterjee, companynsel for the respondent, properly companycedes that he cannot press this point.

facts.text: Offence alleged to have been committed in 1954.

anchor.surface_text: We may add that the offence is alleged to have been companymit- ted in 1954

facts.text: Notice of adjudication sent in 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and numberice of adjudication was sent in 1958

facts.text: Appeal accepted and petition under art.226 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is accepted and the petition under art. 226 dismissed.

Accordingly, the adjudication proceedings were quashed being without jurisdiction.

arguments.court_reasoning: No vested right in particular court or procedure; procedural amendments are retrospective unless constitutional violation

arguments.claim: High Court erred; no vested right affected as amendment only changes venue of trial from Magistrate to Director of Enforcement

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General, who appeared on behalf of the appellant, contends that the High Court was in error in holding that the accused had a vested right to be tried by an ordinary criminal court. He says that the amendment only changed the venue of trial from a Magistrate to the Director of Enforcement in some cases and no vested right was affected.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: may be adjudged by the Director of Enforcement in the manner hereinafter provided, or 23D.  1  For the purpose of adjudging under clause  a  of sub-s

arguments.court_reasoning: Cites and applies Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh: no vested right in particular court or procedure

arguments.claim: No vested or fundamental right to trial by particular court or procedure except where constitutional objection like discrimination or other fundamental right violation

anchor.surface_text: He refers to the decision of this Court in Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. The State of Vindhya Pradesh where Jagannadhadas, J... observed... what is prohibited under article 20 is only conviction or sentence under an ex post facto law and not the trial thereof... A person accused... has no fundamental right to trial by a particular court or by a particular procedure...

arguments.claim: Substantive vested right to be tried by ordinary court existed; alterations in procedure retrospective only unless good reason (Art 20 principles)

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee, the learned counsel for the respondent, urges that a substantive vested right to be tried by an ordinary court existed before the amendment, and he relied on Maxwell 11th Edition, p. 217... He says that there is a good reason if the principles of art. 20 are borne in mind.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: trospective. No right of appeal under the Criminal Procedure Code is affected because numberproceedings had ever been started under the Criminal Proce

arguments.court_reasoning: No vested right in any course of procedure; cites Maxwell and Rao Shiv; no principle in Art 20 makes procedure vested right; no need for express retrospectivity in procedure

arguments.claim: New s.23(1)(a) contravenes Art 20(1) as it prescribes minimum penalty while old s.23(1) allowed Magistrate option of lower fine

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjees next point is that the new s. 23 1  a  contravenes art. 20 1  of the Constitution. He says that s. 23 1   a  prescribes a minimum penalty while under the old s. 23 1  the Magistrate had an option of fixing a fine less than the minimum prescribed under s. 23   1    a .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ive thousand rupees Therefore, numbergreater penalty than might have-been levied under the old section has been prescribed by the new section 23  1

arguments.court_reasoning: New section prescribes maximum penalty ('not exceeding three times... or five thousand rupees'), not minimum; no greater penalty than old provision

arguments.claim: s.23(1)(a) prescribes maximum penalty only, not minimum; no greater penalty than under old s.23(1)

anchor.surface_text: But we are unable to agree with him that the new section prescribes any minimum. What it does prescribe is a maximum. The words not exceeding cover not only the expression three times the value of the foreign exchange but also the words five thousand rupees Therefore, no greater penalty than might have been levied under the old section has been prescribed by the new section 23(1)(a), and consequently there is no breach of art. 20(1)

arguments.claim: Procedural amendments like change in forum or procedure apply retrospectively; no vested right in procedure

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. The State of Vindhya Pradesh a person accused of the commission of an offence has no vested right to be tried by a particular court or a particular procedure except in so far as there is any Constitutional objection... It is well recognized that no person has a vested right in any course of procedure vide Maxwell...

holdings.text: s. 23(1) and s. 23D of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act did not violate art. 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This Court held in Shanti Prasad Jain v. Director of Enforcement 1  that s. 23 1  and s. 23D of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act did number violate art. 14 of the Constitution. Mr. P.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Binding precedent from this Court's decision in Shanti Prasad Jain; conceded by respondent's counsel

holdings.text: The amendment by Act XXXIX of 1957 substituting s. 23(1)(a) and adding s. 23D has retrospective operation for offence in 1954; no vested right to trial by particular court or procedure

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. The State of Vindhya Pradesh 1  a person accused of the commission of an offence has no vested right to be tried by a particular court or a particular procedure except in so far as there is any Constitutional objection by way of discrimination or the violation of any other fundamental right is involved. It is well recognized that no person has a vested right in any course of procedure vide Maxwell...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural amendments are retrospective unless constitutional violation; applies precedent from Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh; no fundamental right in procedure under Art 20

holdings.text: Article 20 prohibits conviction or sentence under ex post facto law but not trial under new procedure

anchor.surface_text: He refers to the decision of this Court in Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. The State of Vindhya Pradesh 2  where Jagannadhadas, J., speaking for the Court, observed at p. 1200 as follows  1  1963 2 S.C.R. 297.  1  1953 S.C.R. 1188. In this context it is necessary to notice that what is prohibited under article 20 is only conviction or sentence under an ex post facto law and not the trial thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Art 20(2) protection to conviction/sentence from trial procedure; cites precedent

holdings.text: New s. 23(1)(a) does not contravene art. 20(1); prescribes maximum penalty only, not minimum or greater than old provision

anchor.surface_text: But we are unable to agree with him that the new section prescribes any minimum. What it does prescribe is a maximum. The words not exceeding cover not only the expression three times the value of the foreign exchange but also the words five thousand rupees Therefore, no greater penalty than might have-been levied under the old section has been prescribed by the new section 23  1    a , and consequently there is no breach of art. 20 1  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of penalty as maximum 'not exceeding'; compares to old s.23(1)

holdings.text: Appeal accepted and petition under art. 226 dismissed

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is accepted and the petition under art. 226 dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on resolutions of constitutional challenges to adjudication proceedings

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in Rao Shiv Bahadur Singh v. The State of Vindhya Pradesh 1  a person accused of the commission of an offence has no vested right to be tried by a particular court or a particular procedure except in so far as there is any Constitutional objection by way of discrimination or the violation of any other fundamental right is involved. It is well recognized that no person has a vested right in any course of procedure vide Maxwell...
In the result the appeal is accepted and the petition under art. 226 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: But we are unable to agree with him that the new section prescribes any minimum. What it does prescribe is a maximum. The words not exceeding cover not only the expression three times the value of the foreign exchange but also the words five thousand rupees Therefore, no greater penalty than might have-been levied under the old section has been prescribed by the new section 23  1    a , and consequently there is no breach of art. 20 1  of the Constitution.
In the result the appeal is accepted and the petition under art. 226 dismissed.
